summary.p: A Dāwit (Ethiopic Psalter) comprised of Mazmur za-Dāwit (Psalms), Maḥāleya nabiyāt (Canticles), Maḥāleya maḥāley (Song of Songs), Weddāsē Māryām (Praises of Mary), and Anqaṣa berhān (Gate of Light).

msItem.title: Dāwit. Psalter
Mazmur za-Dāwit. Psalms
msItem.note: The ancient titles of the chapters are not preserved except at Pss. 128 and 129 (መኅሌት ፡ ዘመዓርጊሁ ፡). Psalms. 1, 20, and 54 have a new heading (ትንቢት ፡ በእንተ ፡ ክርስቶስ ፡); all the others are simply designated as መዝሙር ፡ ዘዳዊት ፡.

msItem.title: Anqaṣa berhān. Gate of Light

foliation.p: Modern pencil foliation in Arabic numerals on the top right corner of each recto folio.

collation.p: Twenty-four sections, the first and last sections are made up of 2 bifolios, with the inner-facing outer leaf cut to a stub, perhaps acting as an endpaper/protection for the rest of the book block. The other sections are made up of 4 bifolios each.

layout.p: Folios 4r-172r: Single columns, 15 to 20 lines per leaf.
Folios 172v-187v: Double columns, 15 to 20 lines per leaf.
Folios have been pricked and scored to assist in writing.

handNote.p: Written in a Ge'ez script, in black and red ink, by a single hand.

additions.p: Marginalia: The manuscript contains many erasures and corrections by a second hand.
On 1v, five lines with the beginning of a short calendar for the commemoration of saints.
On 2r, a genealogy in Amharic: ኈልቈ ፡ ዘመድ ። ዋግ ፡ ሹም ፡ ዘረ ፡ ከል ፡ ቢወልድ ፡ ጅር ፡ ባሕራን ። ጅር ፡ ባሕራ ፡ ብትወልድ ፡ አምባ ፡ አፍርስን ። አምባ ፡ ብትወልድ ፡ ዕፍረትን ።
On 2v, two short fragments from the Me'raf (wedding celebration) with musical notation.
On 2v-3v, a short calendar for the commemoration of saints: ሠረቀ ፡ መስከረም ፡ እምአሚሩ ፡ ዮሐንስ ፡ መጥመቅ ፡ ወበርተሎሜዎስ ፡ ወኢዮብ ፡ ጻድቅ ፡ ወራጉኤል ፡ መልአክ ፡ ....
On 187va typical benediction for the scribe of the manuscript.
On 187v-188v a fragment of the Mastabeqwe' (መስተብቍዕ).
On 187v-188v penitential instructions in the lower margin in Amharic: የቈረበ ፡ ወርኅ ፡ ይከልከል ፡ ቃር ፡ ባቃረው ፡ ጊዜ ፡ አቡነ ፡ ዘበሰማያት ፡ የማያውቅ ፡ ተዝካር ፡ አይብላ ፡ ቢበላም : ቀን ፡ ይጹም ፡.
On 189r-190r an extract in Amharic of an 'Ordinance of the Church': በስመ ፡ … ሥርዓተ ፡ ቤተ ፡ ክርስቲዮን ፡ ቁርባን ፡ ምን ፡ ቀን ፡ ተዠመረ ፡ የጸሎት ፡ ሐሙስ ፡ ዕ]ለት ፡ ማን ፡ ዠመረ ፡ ክርስቶስ ፡ አለ ፡ ማን ፡ ቈረቡ ፡ ሐዋርያት ፡ ከአልዓዛር ፡ ቤት ፡….
On 191r the end of a genealogy, different from the one recorded on 2r.
On 191v an Ethiopic syllabary in the halähamä order followed by ciphers.

binding.p: Ethiopic binding. Remnants of a quarter-leather covering that was adhered across the spine onto the boards. The outer sides of the boards are polished smooth from use, the exposed areas that were covered with leather are rougher and lighter in tone, and the inside faces or the board are similarly rough. Exposed spine and wooden boards; the back board has a split down the middle, this has been bound and rejoined with thick thread similar to the sewing, and appears to be contemporary with the binding. The back board also has two holes that appear to be from natural knots in the wood. Although the endbands are lost, sewing holes show they were anchored at every section. Unsupported sewing at 4 stations (two even pairs of sewing stations). The sewing is laced into the boards as an integral part of the sewing process and is done in separate pairs with each pair sewn using a different thread.

Raw hide leather satchel. The main container is made of a single piece of hide, folded up and sewn along the base and sides. Three flaps are attached to the top of the sides and back. The two at the sides fold over the top and are cut to meet. The back flap folds over them, slotting into a leather/hide strap (laced with leather thongs) that wraps horizontally around the top quarter of the satchel. A long leather strap is stitched to the inner top centre of the back panel and lies along the inside of the satchel emerging through a cut hole on the front panel towards the top edge, this is to assist in removing the manuscript from the satchel. All the hide of the satchel is faced inwards so that the hair side is in contact with the book.

Inside the satchel there is a lump of several pieces of leather laminated together, with the remnants of paper, adhesive and skinned paper on the reverse, on the top side the leather appears to have been blind tooled with a roll. It appears to be a leather stop or part of a strap, whether it was part of this manuscript or not is not obvious.

provenance.p: Marginalia on 1r and 1v indicate the manuscript belonged to a church at Guna-Guna.
The name of the original owner was erased. Another name, Adera Krestos is mentioned on 187r.

James Ludovic Lindsay, 26th Earl of Crawford (1847-1913) . The inner upper cover (pastedown) bears the armorial bookplate (Ex Libris) identifying the codex as having once been part of the Bibliotheca Lindesiana, the private library of the Lindsay family, Earls of Crawford and Balcarres | Armorial bookplate (Ex Libris): ARMS: Quarterly, 1st and 4th, Gules a fess chequy Argent and Azure; 2nd and 3rd, Or a lion rampant Gules, debruised of a ribbon in bend Sable. CREST: a swan’s head, neck, and wings proper, issuing from an antique ducal coronet Or. SUPPORTERS: two lions, rampant guardant Gules. MOTTO in Latin: Endure fort (Endure bravely) | Bibliotheca Lindesiana | pencilled: Pencilled on left inner upper cover: Ethiopic MSS | No 15.
Purchased by Enriqueta Rylands (1843–1908) in 1901 from James Ludovic Lindsay, 26th Earl of Crawford (1847-1913).
